|Title=Know the main risk of rapid correction of hyponatremia
|Description=Acknowledge the risk of central pontine myelinolysis (CPM)
|Rubric=Management
|Contributors=P Rieu; B Moulin; M Flamant
|Order=28}}
If the hyponatremia is chronic, the disorder must be corrected very carefully, as there is a high risk of centropontine myelinolysis or osmotic demyelination (a rare but formidable complication). This risk is increased when chronic hyponatraemia has been corrected too quickly (''> 10 mmol/L/24 h'') and when this hyponatraemia evolved in a context of hypoxia, malnutrition and ethylism.

question.title: What is the main risk of rapid correction of hyponatremia?
question.description: A question about the complications of hyponatremia correction

option_a.title: Osmotic demyelination
option_a.description: A rare but serious complication of hyponatremia correction

option_b.title: Central pontine myelinolysis (CPM)
option_b.description: A serious complication of rapid hyponatremia correction

option_c.title: Hyponatremic encephalopathy
option_c.description: A condition characterized by swelling of brain cells due to hyponatremia

option_d.title: Electrolyte imbalance
option_d.description: A condition where the levels of essential minerals in the blood are out of balance

correct_option.title: A
correct_option.description: The letter of the correct option
